verses.textLa: Accidit autem ut occurreret Absalom servis David, sedens mulo: cumque ingressus fuisset mulus subter condensam quercum et magnam, adhæsit caput eius quercui: et illo suspenso inter cælum et terram, mulus, cui insederat, pertransivit.

verses.textEn: Then a certain one saw this and reported it to Joab, saying, “I saw Absalom hanging from an oak.”
verses.textLa: Vidit autem hoc quispiam, et nunciavit Ioab, dicens: Vidi Absalom pendere de quercu.

verses.textEn: And Joab said to the man who had reported it to him, “If you saw him, why did you not stab him to the ground, and I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a belt?”
verses.textLa: Et ait Ioab viro, qui nunciaverat ei: Si vidisti, quare non confodisti eum cum terra, et ego dedissem tibi decem argenti siclos, et unum balteum?

verses.textEn: And he said to Joab: “Even if you weighed out to my hands one thousand silver coins, I would never lay my hands on the son of the king. For in our hearing the king ordered you and Abishai and Ittai, saying, ‘Keep for me the boy Absalom.’
verses.textLa: Qui dixit ad Ioab: Si appenderes in manibus meis mille argenteos, nequaquam mitterem manum meam in filium regis: audientibus enim nobis præcepit rex tibi, et Abisai, et Ethai, dicens: Custodite mihi puerum Absalom.

verses.textEn: Then too, if I had acted with such audacity, against my own life, this would never have been able to be hidden from the king. And would you then have stood by my side?”
verses.textLa: Sed et si fecissem contra animam meam audacter, nequaquam hoc regem latere potuisset, et tu stares ex adverso?

verses.textEn: And Joab said, “It will not be as you wish. Instead, I will be assailing him in your sight.” Then he took three lances in his hand, and he fixed them in the heart of Absalom. And while he was still clinging to life upon the oak,
verses.textLa: Et ait Ioab: Non sicut tu vis, sed aggrediar eum coram te. Tulit ergo tres lanceas in manu sua, et infixit eas in corde Absalom: cumque adhuc palpitaret hærens in quercu,

verses.textEn: ten young men, armor bearers of Joab, ran up, and striking him, they killed him.
verses.textLa: cucurrerunt decem iuvenes armigeri Ioab, et percutientes interfecerunt eum.

verses.textEn: Then Joab sounded the trumpet, and he held back the people, lest they pursue Israel in their flight, for he was willing to spare the multitude.
verses.textLa: Cecinit autem Ioab buccina, et retinuit populum, ne persequeretur fugientem Israel, volens parcere multitudini.

verses.textEn: And they took Absalom, and they threw him into a great pit in the forest. And they piled an exceedingly great heap of stones over him. But all of Israel fled to their own tents.
verses.textLa: Et tulerunt Absalom, et proiecerunt eum in saltu, in foveam grandem, et comportaverunt super eum acervum lapidum magnum nimis: omnis autem Israel fugit in tabernacula sua.

verses.textEn: Now Absalom had raised up for himself, when he was still alive, a monument, which is in the Valley of the King. For he said, “I have no son, and so this shall be the memorial to my name.” And he called the monument by his own name. And it is called the Hand of Absalom, even to this day.
verses.textLa: Porro Absalom erexerat sibi, cum adhuc viveret, titulum qui est in Valle regis: dixerat enim: Non habeo filium, et hoc erit monimentum nominis mei. Vocavitque titulum nomine suo, et appellatur Manus Absalom, usque ad hanc diem.

verses.textEn: Then Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said, “I will run and report to the king that the Lord has accomplished judgment for him, from the hand of his enemies.”
verses.textLa: Achimaas autem filius Sadoc, ait: Curram, et nunciabo regi, quia iudicium fecerit ei Dominus de manu inimicorum eius.

verses.textEn: And Joab said to him: “You shall not be the messenger on this day. Instead, you shall report on another day. I am not willing for you to give the report today, because the son of the king is dead.”
verses.textLa: Ad quem Ioab dixit: Non eris nuncius in hac die, sed nunciabis in alia: hodie nolo te nunciare, filius enim regis est mortuus.

verses.textEn: Then Joab said to Hushai, “Go, and report to the king what you have seen.” Hushai reverenced Joab, and he ran.
verses.textLa: Et ait Ioab Chusi: Vade, et nuncia regi quæ vidisti. Adoravit Chusi Ioab, et cucurrit.

verses.textEn: And Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said to Joab again, “What prevents me from running after Hushai also?” And Joab said to him: “Why do you want to run, my son? You would not be the bearer of good news.”
verses.textLa: Rursus autem Achimaas filius Sadoc dixit ad Ioab: Quid impedit si etiam ego curram post Chusi? Dixitque ei Ioab: Quid vis currere fili mi? Non eris boni nuncii baiulus.

verses.textEn: And he responded, “But what if I do run?” And he said to him, “Run.” Then Ahimaaz, running along a shorter way, passed Hushai.
verses.textLa: Qui respondit: Quid enim si cucurrero? Et ait ei: Curre. Currens ergo Achimaas per viam compendii, transivit Chusi.

verses.textEn: Now David was sitting between the two gates. Truly, the watchman, who was at the summit of the gate upon the wall, lifting up his eyes, saw a man running alone.
verses.textLa: David autem sedebat inter duas portas: speculator vero, qui erat in fastigio portæ super murum, elevans oculos, vidit hominem currentem solum.

verses.textEn: And crying out, he told the king. And the king said, “If he is alone, there is good news in his mouth.” But as he was advancing and drawing nearer,
verses.textLa: Et exclamans indicavit regi: dixitque rex: Si solus est, bonus est nuncius in ore eius. Properante autem illo, et accedente propius,

verses.textEn: the watchman saw another man running. And so, crying out from the height, he said: “Another man has appeared, running alone.” And the king said, “This one also is a good messenger.”
verses.textLa: vidit speculator hominem alterum currentem, et vociferans in culmine, ait: Apparet mihi alter homo currens solus. Dixitque rex: Et iste bonus est nuncius.

verses.textEn: Then the watchman said, “The running of the closest one seems like the running of Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok.” And the king said, “He is a good man, and he arrives bearing good news.”
verses.textLa: Speculator autem: Contemplor, ait, cursum prioris, quasi cursum Achimaas filii Sadoc. Et ait rex: Vir bonus est: et nuncium portans bonum, venit.

verses.textEn: Then, Ahimaaz, crying out, said to the king, “Be well, O king.” And reverencing the king prone on the ground before him, he said, “Blessed be the Lord your God, who has enclosed the men who had lifted up their hands against my lord the king.”
verses.textLa: Clamans autem Achimaas, dixit ad regem: Salve rex. Et adorans regem coram eo pronus in terram, ait: Benedictus Dominus Deus tuus, qui conclusit homines qui levaverunt manus suas contra dominum meum regem.

verses.textEn: And the king said, “Is there peace for the boy Absalom?” And Ahimaaz said: “I saw a great tumult, O king, when your servant Joab sent me, your servant. I know nothing else.”
verses.textLa: Et ait rex: Est ne pax puero Absalom? Dixitque Achimaas: Vidi tumultum magnum, cum mitteret Ioab servus tuus, o rex, me servum tuum: nescio aliud.

verses.textEn: And the king said to him, “Pass, and stand here.” And when he had passed and stood still,
verses.textLa: Ad quem rex: Transi, ait, et sta hic. Cumque ille transisset, et staret,

verses.textEn: Hushai appeared. And approaching, he said: “I bear good news, my lord the king. For today the Lord has judged for you, from the hand of all who had risen up against you.”
verses.textLa: apparuit Chusi: et veniens ait: Bonum apporto nuncium, domine mi rex: iudicavit enim pro te Dominus hodie de manu omnium qui surrexerunt contra te.

verses.textEn: But the king said to Hushai, “Is there peace for the boy Absalom?” And responding, Hushai said to him, “May the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise against him for evil, be as the boy is.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem rex ad Chusi: Est ne pax puero Absalom? Cui respondens Chusi, Fiant, inquit, sicut puer, inimici domini mei regis, et universi qui consurgunt adversus eum in malum.

verses.textEn: And so the king, being greatly saddened, ascended to the upper room of the gate, and he wept. And as he went, he was speaking in this manner: “My son Absalom! Absalom my son! Who can grant to me that I may die on your behalf? Absalom, my son! My son, Absalom!”
verses.textLa: Contristatus itaque rex, ascendit cœnaculum portæ, et flevit. Et sic loquebatur, vadens: Fili mi Absalom, Absalom fili mi: quis mihi tribuat ut ego moriar pro te, Absalom fili mi, fili mi Absalom?

verses.textEn: Now it was reported to Joab that the king was weeping and mourning for his son.
verses.textLa: Nunciatum est autem Ioab quod rex fleret et lugeret filium suum:

verses.textEn: And so the victory on that day was turned into mourning for all the people. For the people heard it said on that day, “The king is grieving over his son.”
verses.textLa: et versa est victoria in luctum in die illa omni populo: audivit enim populus in die illa dici: Dolet rex super filio suo.

verses.textEn: And the people declined to enter the city on that day, in the manner that the people were accustomed to decline if they had turned and fled from battle.
verses.textLa: Et declinavit populus in die illa ingredi civitatem, quomodo declinare solet populus versus et fugiens de prælio.

verses.textEn: And the king covered his head, and he was crying out in a great voice: “My son, Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.textLa: Porro rex operuit caput suum, et clamabat voce magna: Fili mi Absalom, Absalom fili mi, fili mi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Joab, entering to the king in the house, said: “Today you have shamed the faces of all your servants, who saved your life, and the lives of your sons and your daughters, and the lives of your wives, and the lives of your concubines.
verses.textLa: Ingressus ergo Ioab ad regem in domum, dixit: Confudisti hodie vultus omnium servorum tuorum, qui salvam fecerunt animam tuam, et animam filiorum tuorum, et filiarum tuarum, et animam uxorum tuarum, et animam concubinarum tuarum.

verses.textEn: You love those who hate you, and you hate those who love you. And you have revealed this day that you have no concern for your leaders and for your servants. And truly, I know now that if Absalom had lived, and if we all had been killed, then it would have pleased you.
verses.textLa: Diligis odientes te, et odio habes diligentes te: et ostendisti hodie quia non curas de ducibus tuis, et de servis tuis: et vere cognovi modo, quia si Absalom viveret, et omnes nos occubuissemus, tunc placeret tibi.

verses.textEn: Now then, rise up and go out, and speak so as to make amends to your servants. For I swear to you by the Lord that if you will not go forth, not even one person will be left with you this night. And this will be worse for you than all the evils that have come to you, from your youth even to the present.”
verses.textLa: Nunc igitur surge, et procede, et alloquens satisfac servis tuis: iuro enim tibi per Dominum, quod si non exieris, ne unus quidem remansurus sit tecum nocte hac: et peius erit hoc tibi, quam omnia mala, quæ venerunt super te ab adolescentia tua usque in præsens.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the king rose up, and he sat at the gate. And it was announced to all the people that the king was sitting at the gate. And the entire multitude went before the king. But Israel fled to their own tents.
verses.textLa: Surrexit ergo rex et sedit in porta: et omni populo nunciatum est quod rex sederet in porta: venitque universa multitudo coram rege: Israel autem fugit in tabernacula sua.

verses.textEn: And all the people were conflicted, in all the tribes of Israel, saying: “The king has freed us from the hand of our enemies. He himself saved us from the hand of the Philistines. But now he flees from the land for the sake of Absalom.
verses.textLa: Omnis quoque populus certabat in cunctis tribubus Israel, dicens: Rex liberavit nos de manu inimicorum nostrorum, ipse salvavit nos de manu Philisthinorum: et nunc fugit de terra propter Absalom.

verses.textEn: But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in the war. How long will you be silent, and not lead back the king?”
verses.textLa: Absalom autem, quem unximus super nos, mortuus est in bello: usquequo siletis, et non reducitis regem?

verses.textEn: Then truly, king David sent to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, saying: “Speak to those greater by birth of Judah, saying: ‘Why have you arrived last to lead back the king into his house? (For the talk in all of Israel had reached the king in his house.)
verses.textLa: Rex vero David misit ad Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotes, dicens: Loquimini ad maiores natu Iuda, dicentes: Cur venitis novissimi ad reducendum regem in domum suam? (Sermo autem omnis Israel pervenerat ad regem in domo eius.)

verses.textEn: You are my brothers; you are my bone and my flesh. Why are you the last to lead back the king?’
verses.textLa: Fratres mei vos, os meum, et caro mea vos, quare novissimi reducitis regem?

verses.textEn: And say to Amasa: ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do these things, and may he add these other things, if you will not be the leader of the military in my sight, for all time, in the place of Joab.’ ”
verses.textLa: Et Amasæ dicite: Nonne os meum, et caro mea es? Hæc faciat mihi Deus, et hæc addat, si non magister militiæ fueris coram me omni tempore pro Ioab.

verses.textEn: And he inclined the heart of all the men of Judah, as if one man. And they sent to the king, saying, “Return, you and all your servants.”
verses.textLa: Et inclinavit cor omnium virorum Iuda, quasi viri unius: miseruntque ad regem, dicentes: Revertere tu, et omnes servi tui.

verses.textEn: And the king returned. And he went as far as the Jordan, and all of Judah went as far as Gilgal, so as to meet the king, and to lead him across the Jordan.
verses.textLa: Et reversus est rex: et venit usque ad Iordanem, et omnis Iuda venit usque in Galgalam ut occurreret regi, et traduceret eum Iordanem.

verses.textEn: And Shimei, the son of Gera, the son of Benjamin, from Bahurim, hurried and descended with the men of Judah to meet king David,
verses.textLa: Festinavit autem Semei filius Gera filii Iemini de Bahurim, et descendit cum viris Iuda in occursum regis David

verses.textEn: with one thousand men from Benjamin, and with Ziba, the servant from the house of Saul. And with him were his fifteen sons and twenty servants. And going into the Jordan,
verses.textLa: cum mille viris de Beniamin, et Siba puer de domo Saul: et quindecim filii eius, ac viginti servi erant cum eo: et irrumpentes Iordanem, ante regem

verses.textEn: they crossed the fords before the king, so that they might lead across the house of the king, and might act in accord with his order. Then, Shimei, the son of Gera, prostrating himself before the king after he had now gone across the Jordan,
verses.textLa: transierunt vada, ut traducerent domum regis, et facerent iuxta iussionem eius: Semei autem filius Gera prostratus coram rege, cum iam transisset Iordanem,

verses.textEn: said to him: “May you not impute to me, my lord, the iniquity, nor call to mind the injuries, of your servant in the day that you, my lord the king, departed from Jerusalem. And may you not store it up in your heart, O king.
verses.textLa: dixit ad eum: Ne reputes mihi domine mi iniquitatem, neque memineris iniuriarum servi tui in die qua egressus es domine mi rex de Ierusalem, neque ponas rex in corde tuo.

verses.textEn: For as your servant, I acknowledge my sin. And for this reason, today, I arrive as the first from all the house of Joseph, and I descend to meet my lord the king.”
verses.textLa: Agnosco enim servus tuus peccatum meum: et idcirco hodie primus veni de omni domo Ioseph, descendique in occursum domini mei regis.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, responding, said, “Should not Shimei, because of these words, be killed, since he cursed the Christ of the Lord?”
verses.textLa: Respondens vero Abisai filius Sarviæ, dixit: Numquid pro his verbis non occidetur Semei, quia maledixit Christo Domini?

verses.textEn: And David said: “What is it to me and to all of you, O sons of Zeruiah? Why are you acting toward me this day like Satan? Why should any man be put to death on this day in Israel? Or do you not know that today I have been made king over Israel?”
verses.textLa: Et ait David: Quid mihi, et vobis filii Sarviæ? Cur efficimini mihi hodie in Satan? Ergo ne hodie interficietur vir in Israel? An ignoro hodie me factum regem super Israel?

verses.textEn: And the king said to Shimei, “You shall not die.” And he swore to him.
verses.textLa: Et ait rex Semei: Non morieris. Iuravitque ei.

verses.textEn: And Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, descended to meet the king, with unwashed feet and uncut beard. And he had not washed his garments from the day that the king had departed, until the day of his return in peace.
verses.textLa: Miphiboseth quoque filius Saul descendit in occursum regis illotis pedibus, et intonsa barba: vestesque suas non laverat a die qua egressus fuerat rex, usque ad diem reversionis eius in pace.

verses.textEn: And when he had met the king at Jerusalem, the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?”
verses.textLa: Cumque Ierusalem occurrisset regi, dixit ei rex: Quare non venisti mecum Miphiboseth?

verses.textEn: And in response, he said: “My lord the king, my servant spurned me. And I, your servant, spoke to him so that he might saddle a donkey for me, and I might climb upon it and go with the king. For I, your servant, am lame.
verses.textLa: Et respondens ait: Mi domine rex, servus meus contempsit me: dixique ei ego famulus tuus ut sterneret mihi asinum, et ascendens abirem cum rege: claudus enim sum servus tuus.

verses.textEn: Moreover, he also accused me, your servant, to you, my lord the king. But you, my lord the king, are like an Angel of God. Do whatever is pleasing to you.
verses.textLa: Insuper et accusavit me servum tuum ad te dominum meum regem: tu autem domine mi rex, sicut Angelus Dei es, fac quod placitum est tibi.

verses.textEn: For my father’s house was deserving of nothing but death before my lord the king. Yet you have placed me, your servant, among the guests of your table. Therefore, what just complaint might I have? Or what else can I cry out to the king?”
verses.textLa: Neque enim fuit domus patris mei, nisi morti obnoxia domino meo regi: tu autem posuisti me servum tuum inter convivas mensæ tuæ: quid ergo habeo iustæ querelæ? Aut quid possum ultra vociferari ad regem?

verses.textEn: Then the king said to him: “Why are you still speaking? What I have spoken is fixed. You and Ziba shall divide the possessions.”
verses.textLa: Ait ergo ei rex: Quid ultra loqueris? Fixum est quod locutus sum: tu, et Siba dividite possessiones.

verses.textEn: And Mephibosheth responded to the king, “But now let him take it all, since my lord the king has been returned peacefully into his own house.”
verses.textLa: Responditque Miphiboseth regi: Etiam cuncta accipiat, postquam reversus est dominus meus rex pacifice in domum suam.

verses.textEn: Likewise, Barzillai the Gileadite, descending from Rogelim, led the king across the Jordan, having prepared also to follow him beyond the river.
verses.textLa: Berzellai quoque Galaadites, descendens de Rogelim, traduxit regem Iordanem, paratus etiam ultra fluvium prosequi eum.

verses.textEn: Now Barzillai the Gileadite was very old, that is, eighty years old. And he provided the king with sustenance when he was staying at the encampment. For indeed, he was an exceedingly rich man.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Berzellai Galaadites senex valde, id est, octogenarius, et ipse præbuit alimenta regi, cum moraretur in castris: fuit quippe vir dives nimis.

verses.textEn: And so the king said to Barzillai, “Come with me, so that you may rest securely with me in Jerusalem.”
verses.textLa: Dixit itaque rex ad Berzellai: Veni mecum, ut requiescas securus mecum in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And Barzillai said to the king: “How many days remain in the years of my life, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
verses.textLa: Et ait Berzellai ad regem: Quot sunt dies annorum vitæ meæ, ut ascendam cum rege in Ierusalem?

verses.textEn: Today I am eighty years old. Are my senses quick to discern sweet and bitter? Or is food and drink able to delight your servant? Or can I still hear the voice of men and women singers? Why should your servant be a burden to my lord the king?
verses.textLa: Octogenarius sum hodie: numquid vigent sensus mei ad discernendum suave, aut amarum? Aut delectare potest servum tuum cibus et potus? Vel audire possum ultra vocem cantorum, atque cantatricum? Quare servus tuus sit oneri domino meo regi?

verses.textEn: I, your servant, shall proceed a little ways from the Jordan with you. I am not in need of this recompense.
verses.textLa: Paululum procedam famulus tuus ab Iordane tecum: non indigeo hac vicissitudine,

verses.textEn: But I beg you that I, your servant, may be returned and may die in my own city, and may be buried beside the sepulcher of my father and my mother. But there is your servant Chimham; let him go with you, my lord the king. And do for him whatever seems good to you.”
verses.textLa: sed obsecro ut revertar servus tuus, et moriar in civitate mea, et sepeliar iuxta sepulchrum patris mei, et matris meæ. Est autem servus tuus Chamaam, ipse vadat tecum, domine mi rex, et fac ei quidquid tibi bonum videtur.
verses.notes: Barzillai refers to his own servant, when talking to David, as “your servant,” because he considers himself and all of his family and servants as servants to king David.

verses.textEn: And so the king said to him: “Let Chimham cross over with me, and I will do for him whatever will be pleasing to you. And all that you ask of me, you shall obtain.”
verses.textLa: Dixit itaque ei rex: Mecum transeat Chamaam, et ego faciam ei quidquid tibi placuerit, et omne, quod petieris a me, impetrabis.

verses.textEn: And when the entire people and the king had crossed over the Jordan, the king kissed Barzillai, and he blessed him. And he returned to his own place.
verses.textLa: Cumque transisset universus populus et rex Iordanem, osculatus est rex Berzellai, et benedixit ei: et ille reversus est in locum suum.

verses.textEn: Then the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went with him. Now all the people of Judah had led the king across, but only as much as one half part of the people of Israel were there.
verses.textLa: Transivit ergo rex in Galgalam, et Chamaam cum eo. Omnis autem populus Iuda traduxerat regem, et media tantum pars adfuerat de populo Israel.

verses.textEn: And so, all the men of Israel, running to the king, said to him: “Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you away. And why have they led the king and his house across the Jordan, and all the men of David with him?”
verses.textLa: Itaque omnes viri Israel concurrentes ad regem dixerunt ei: Quare te furati sunt fratres nostri viri Iuda, et traduxerunt regem et domum eius Iordanem, omnesque viros David cum eo?

verses.textEn: And all the men of Judah responded to the men of Israel: “Because the king is nearer to me. Why are you angry over this matter? Have we eaten anything belonging to the king, or have any gifts been given to us?”
verses.textLa: Et respondit omnis vir Iuda ad viros Israel: Quia mihi propior est rex: cur irasceris super hac re? Numquid comedimus aliquid ex rege, aut munera nobis data sunt?

verses.textEn: And the men of Israel responded to the men of Judah, and said: “I have the greater amount, ten parts, with the king, and so David belongs to me more so than to you. Why have you caused me injury, and why was it not announced to me first, so that I might lead back my king?” But the men of Judah answered more firmly than the men of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et respondit vir Israel ad viros Iuda, et ait: Decem partibus maior ego sum apud regem, magisque ad me pertinet David quam ad te: cur fecisti mihi iniuriam, et non mihi nunciatum est priori, ut reducerem regem meum? Durius autem responderunt viri Iuda viris Israel.

verses.textEn: And it happened that there was, in that place, a man of Belial, whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a man of Benjamin. And he sounded the trumpet, and he said: “There is no portion for us in David, nor any inheritance in the son of Jesse. Return to your own tents, O Israel.”
verses.textLa: Accidit quoque ut ibi esset vir Belial, nomine Seba, filius Bochri, vir Iemineus: et cecinit buccina, et ait: Non est nobis pars in David, neque hereditas in filio Isai: revertere in tabernacula tua Israel.

verses.textEn: And all of Israel separated from David, and they were following Sheba, the son of Bichri. But the men of Judah clung to their king, from the Jordan as far as Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et separatus est omnis Israel a David, secutusque est Seba filium Bochri: viri autem Iuda adhæserunt regi suo a Iordane usque Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And when the king had entered his house at Jerusalem, he took the ten women concubines, whom he had left behind to care for the house, and he put them into custody, allowing them provisions. But he did not enter to them. Instead, they were enclosed, even until the day of their deaths, living as widows.
verses.textLa: Cumque venisset rex in domum suam in Ierusalem, tulit decem mulieres concubinas, quas dereliquerat ad custodiendam domum, et tradidit eas in custodiam, alimenta eis præbens: et non est ingressus ad eas, sed erant clausæ usque in diem mortis suæ in viduitate viventes.

verses.textEn: Then the king said to Amasa, “Summon to me all the men of Judah on the third day, and you shall be present also.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem rex Amasæ: Convoca mihi omnes viros Iuda in diem tertium, et tu adesto præsens.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Amasa went away, so that he might summon Judah. But he delayed beyond the agreed time that the king had appointed to him.
verses.textLa: Abiit ergo Amasa ut convocaret Iudam, et moratus est extra placitum quod ei constituerat rex.

verses.textEn: And David said to Abishai: “Now Sheba, the son of Bichri, will afflict us more so than Absalom did. Therefore, take the servants of your lord, and pursue him, otherwise he may find fortified cities, and escape from us.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem David ad Abisai: Nunc magis afflicturus est nos Seba filius Bochri quam Absalom: tolle igitur servos domini tui, et persequere eum, ne forte inveniat civitates munitas, et effugiat nos.

verses.textEn: And so, the men of Joab departed with him, along with the Cherethites and the Pelethites. And all the able-bodied men went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, the son of Bichri.
verses.textLa: Egressi sunt ergo cum eo viri Ioab, Cerethi quoque et Phelethi: et omnes robusti exierunt de Ierusalem ad persequendum Seba filium Bochri.

verses.textEn: And when they were beside the great stone, which is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was wearing a close-fitting coat of equal length with his garment. And over these, he was girded with a sword hanging down to his thigh, in a scabbard which was made so that the sword could be removed with the least motion, and then strike.
verses.textLa: Cumque illi essent iuxta lapidem grandem, qui est in Gabaon, Amasa veniens occurrit eis. Porro Ioab vestitus erat tunica stricta ad mensuram habitus sui, et desuper accinctus gladio dependente usque ad ilia, in vagina, qui fabricatus levi motu egredi poterat, et percutere.

verses.textEn: Then Joab said to Amasa, “Be well, my brother.” And he held Amasa by the chin with his right hand, as if to kiss him.
verses.textLa: Dixit itaque Ioab ad Amasam: Salve mi frater. Et tenuit manu dextera mentum Amasæ, quasi osculans eum.

verses.textEn: But Amasa did not notice the sword that Joab had. And he struck him in the side, and his intestines poured out to the ground. And he did not inflict a second wound, and he died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai pursued Sheba, the son of Bichri.
verses.textLa: Porro Amasa non observavit gladium, quem habebat Ioab, qui percussit eum in latere, et effudit intestina eius in terram, nec secundum vulnus apposuit, et mortuus est. Ioab autem, et Abisai frater eius persecuti sunt Seba filium Bochri.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, certain men, from the company of Joab, when they had stopped beside the dead body of Amasa, said: “Behold, the one who wished to be in the place of Joab, the companion of David.”
verses.textLa: Interea quidam viri, cum stetissent iuxta cadaver Amasæ, de sociis Ioab, dixerunt: Ecce qui esse voluit pro Ioab comes David.

verses.textEn: Now Amasa was covered with blood, and was lying in the middle of the road. A certain man saw this, with all the people standing nearby to look at him, and he removed Amasa from the road into a field. And he covered him with a garment, so that those passing by would not stop because of him.
verses.textLa: Amasa autem conspersus sanguine, iacebat in media via. Vidit hoc quidam vir quod subsisteret omnis populus ad videndum eum, et amovit Amasam de via in agrum, operuitque eum vestimento, ne subsisterent transeuntes propter eum.

verses.textEn: Then, when he had been removed from the road, all the men continued on, following Joab in the pursuit of Sheba, the son of Bichri.
verses.textLa: Amoto ergo illo de via, transibat omnis vir sequens Ioab ad persequendum Seba filium Bochri.

verses.textEn: Now he had passed through all the tribes of Israel into Abel and Bethmaacah. And all the elect men had gathered together to him.
verses.textLa: Porro ille transierat per omnes tribus Israel in Abelam, et Bethmaacha: omnesque viri electi congregati fuerant ad eum.

verses.textEn: And so, they went and besieged him at Abel and Bethmaacah. And they surrounded the city with siege works, and the city was blockaded. Then the entire crowd who were with Joab strove to destroy the walls.
verses.textLa: Venerunt itaque et oppugnabant eum in Abela, et in Bethmaacha, et circumdederunt munitionibus civitatem, et obsessa est urbs: omnis autem turba, quæ erat cum Ioab, moliebatur destruere muros.

verses.textEn: And a wise woman exclaimed from the city: “Listen, listen, and say to Joab: Draw near, and I will speak with you.”
verses.textLa: Et exclamavit mulier sapiens de civitate: Audite, audite, dicite Ioab: Appropinqua huc, et loquar tecum.

verses.textEn: And when he had drawn near to her, she said to him, “Are you Joab?” And he responded, “I am.” And she spoke in this way to him, “Listen to the words of your handmaid.” He responded, “I am listening.”
verses.textLa: Qui cum accessisset ad eam, ait illi: Tu es Ioab? Et ille respondit: Ego. Ad quem sic locuta est: Audi sermones ancillæ tuæ. Qui respondit: Audio.

verses.textEn: And again she spoke: “A word was said in the old proverb, ‘Those who would inquire, let them inquire in Abel.’ And so they would reach a conclusion.
verses.textLa: Rursumque illa, Sermo, inquit, dicebatur in veteri proverbio: Qui interrogant, interrogent in Abela: et sic perficiebant.

verses.textEn: Am I not the one who responds with the truth in Israel? And yet you are seeking to overthrow the city, and to overturn a mother in Israel! Why would you cast down the inheritance of the Lord?”
verses.textLa: Nonne ego sum quæ respondeo veritatem in Israel, et tu quæris subvertere civitatem, et evertere matrem in Israel? Quare præcipitas hereditatem Domini?

verses.textEn: And responding, Joab said: “May this be far, may this be far from me! May I not cast down, and may I not demolish.
verses.textLa: Respondensque Ioab, ait: Absit, absit hoc a me: non præcipito, neque demolior.

verses.textEn: The matter is not as you said. Rather, a man from mount Ephraim, Sheba, the son of Bichri, by name, has lifted up his hand against king David. Deliver him alone, and we will withdraw from the city.” And the woman said to Joab, “Behold, his head will be thrown down to you from the wall.’
verses.textLa: Non sic se habet res, sed homo de monte Ephraim Seba, filius Bochri cognomine, levavit manum suam contra regem David: tradite illum solum, et recedemus a civitate. Et ait mulier ad Ioab: Ecce caput eius mittetur ad te per murum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, she entered to all the people, and she spoke to them wisely. And they cut off the head of Sheba, the son of Bichri, and they threw it down to Joab. And he sounded the trumpet, and they withdrew from the city, each one to his own tent. But Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
verses.textLa: Ingressa est ergo ad omnem populum, et locuta est eis sapienter: qui abscissum caput Seba filii Bochri proiecerunt ad Ioab. Et ille cecinit tuba, et recesserunt ab urbe, unusquisque in tabernacula sua: Ioab autem reversus est Ierusalem ad regem.

verses.textEn: Thus Joab was over the entire army of Israel. And Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was over the Cerethites and Phelethites.
verses.textLa: Fuit ergo Ioab super omnem exercitum Israel: Banaias autem filius Ioiadæ super Cerethæos et Phelethæos.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Adoram was over the tributes. And Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the keeper of records.
verses.textLa: Aduram vero super tributa: porro Iosaphat filius Ahilud, a commentariis.

verses.textEn: Now Sheva was the scribe. And truly Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
verses.textLa: Siva autem, scriba: Sadoc vero et Abiathar, sacerdotes.

verses.textEn: But Ira, the Jairite, was the priest of David.
verses.textLa: Ira autem Iairites erat sacerdos David.

verses.textEn: And a famine occurred, during the days of David, for three years continuously. And David consulted the oracle of the Lord. And the Lord said: “This is because of Saul, and his house of bloodshed. For he killed the Gibeonites.”
verses.textLa: Facta est quoque fames in diebus David tribus annis iugiter: et consuluit David oraculum Domini. Dixitque Dominus: Proper Saul, et domum eius sanguinum, quia occidit Gabaonitas.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the king, calling for the Gibeonites, spoke to them. Now the Gibeonites were not of the sons of Israel, but were the remnant of the Amorites. And the sons of Israel had sworn an oath to them, but Saul wished to strike them in zeal, as if on behalf of the sons of Israel and Judah.
verses.textLa: Vocatis ergo Gabaonitis rex, dixit ad eos. (Porro Gabaonitæ non erant de filiis Israel, sed reliquiæ Amorrhæorum: filii quippe Israel iuraverant eis, et voluit Saul percutere eos zelo, quasi pro filiis Israel et Iuda.)

verses.textEn: Therefore, David said to the Gibeonites: “What shall I do for you? And what shall be your satisfaction, so that you may bless the inheritance of the Lord?”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo David ad Gabaonitas: Quid faciam vobis? Et quod erit vestri piaculum, ut benedicatis hereditati Domini?

verses.textEn: And the Gibeonites said to him: “There is no quarrel for us over silver or gold, but against Saul and against his house. And we do not desire that any man of Israel be put to death.” The king said to them, “Then what do you wish that I should do for you?”
verses.textLa: Dixeruntque ei Gabaonitæ: Non est nobis super argento et auro quæstio, sed contra Saul, et contra domum eius: neque volumus ut interficiatur homo de Israel. Ad quos rex ait: Quid ergo vultis ut faciam vobis?

verses.textEn: And they said to the king: “The man who unjustly afflicted and oppressed us, we ought to destroy in such manner that not even one of his stock may be left behind in all the parts of Israel.
verses.textLa: Qui dixerunt regi: Virum, qui attrivit nos et oppressit inique, ita delere debemus, ut ne unus quidem residuus sit de stirpe eius in cunctis finibus Israel.

verses.textEn: Let seven men from his sons be given to us, so that we may crucify them to the Lord in Gibeon of Saul, formerly the chosen place of the Lord.” And the king said, “I will give them.”
verses.textLa: Dentur nobis septem viri de filiis eius, ut crucifigamus eos Domino in Gabaa Saul, quondam electi Domini. Et ait rex: Ego dabo.

verses.textEn: But the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the oath of the Lord which had been made between David and Jonathan, the son of Saul.
verses.textLa: Pepercitque rex Miphiboseth filio Ionathæ filii Saul, propter iusiurandum Domini, quod fuerat inter David et inter Ionathan filium Saul.

verses.textEn: And so the king took the two sons of Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth, and the five sons of Michal, the daughter of Saul, whom she conceived of Adriel, the son of Barzillai, who was from Meholath,
verses.textLa: Tulit itaque rex duos filios Respha filiæ Aia, quos peperit Sauli, Armoni, et Miphiboseth: et quinque filios Michol filiæ Saul, quos genuerat Hadrieli filio Berzellai, qui fuit de Molathi,

verses.textEn: and he gave them into the hands of the Gibeonites. And they crucified them on a hill in the sight of the Lord. And these seven fell together in the first days of the harvest, when the barley is beginning to be reaped.
verses.textLa: et dedit eos in manus Gabaonitarum: qui crucifixerunt eos in monte coram Domino: et ceciderunt hi septem simul occisi in diebus messis primis, incipiente messione hordei.

verses.textEn: Then Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, taking a haircloth, spread it under herself on a rock, from the beginning of the harvest until water dropped from heaven upon them. And she did not permit the birds to tear them by day, nor the beasts by night.
verses.textLa: Tollens autem Respha filia Aia, cilicium substravit sibi supra petram ab initio messis, donec stillaret aqua super eos de cælo: et non dimisit aves lacerare eos per diem, neque bestias per noctem.

verses.textEn: And it was reported to David what Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done.
verses.textLa: Et nunciata sunt David quæ fecerat Respha, filia Aia, concubina Saul.

verses.textEn: And David went and took the bones of Saul, and the bones of his son Jonathan, from the men of Jabesh Gilead, who had stolen them from the street of Bethshan, where the Philistines had suspended them after they had slain Saul at Gilboa.
verses.textLa: Et abiit David, et tulit ossa Saul, et ossa Ionathæ filii eius a viris Iabes Galaad, qui furati fuerant ea de platea Bethsan, in qua suspenderant eos Philisthiim cum interfecissent Saul in Gelboe:

verses.textEn: And he brought the bones of Saul, and the bones of his son Jonathan, from there. And they collected the bones of those who had been crucified.
verses.textLa: et asportavit inde ossa Saul, et ossa Ionathæ filii eius: et colligentes ossa eorum, qui affixi fuerant,

verses.textEn: And they buried them with the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan, in the land of Benjamin, to the side of the sepulcher of his father Kish. And they did all that the king had instructed. And after these things, God showed favor again to the land.
verses.textLa: sepelierunt ea cum ossibus Saul et Ionathæ filii eius in Terra Beniamin, in latere, in sepulchro Cis patris eius: feceruntque omnia, quæ præceperat rex, et repropitiatus est Deus terræ post hæc.

verses.textEn: Then the Philistines again undertook a battle against Israel. And David descended, and his servants with him, and they fought against the Philistines. But when David grew faint,
verses.textLa: Factum est autem rursum prælium Philisthinorum adversum Israel, et descendit David, et servi eius cum eo, et pugnabant contra Philisthiim. Deficiente autem David,

verses.textEn: Ishbibenob, who was of the ancestry of Arapha, the iron of whose spear weighed three hundred ounces, who had been girded with a new sword, strove to strike down David.
verses.textLa: Iesbibenob, qui fuit de genere Arapha, cuius ferrum hastæ trecentas uncias appendebat, et accinctus erat ense novo, nisus est percutere David.

verses.textEn: And Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, defended him, and striking the Philistine, he killed him. Then David’s men swore an oath to him, saying, “You shall no longer go out to war with us, lest you extinguish the lamp of Israel.”
verses.textLa: Præsidioque ei fuit Abisai filius Sarviæ, et percussum Philisthæum interfecit. Tunc iuraverunt viri David, dicentes: Iam non egredieris nobiscum in bellum, ne extinguas lucernam Israel.

verses.textEn: Also, a second war occurred in Gob against the Philistines. Then Sibbecai from Hushah struck down Saph, from the stock of Arapha, of the ancestry of the giants.
verses.textLa: Secundum quoque bellum fuit in Gob contra Philisthæos: tunc percussit Sobochai de Husati, Saph de stirpe Arapha de genere gigantum.

verses.textEn: Then there was a third war in Gob against the Philistines, in which Adeodatus, a son of the forest, a weaver from Bethlehem, struck down Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like the beam used by a cloth maker.
verses.textLa: Tertium quoque fuit bellum in Gob contra Philisthæos, in quo percussit Adeodatus filius saltus polymitarius Bethlehemites Goliath Gethæum, cuius hastile hastæ erat quasi liciatorium texentium.
verses.notes: The term ‘polymitarius’ refers to fine weaving, with many colors; whereas the term ‘texentium’ refers to the coarse weaving of fabrics.

verses.textEn: A fourth battle was in Gath. In that place, there was a lofty man, who had six digits on each hand and each foot, that is, twenty-four in all, and he was from the origins of Arapha.
verses.textLa: Quartum bellum fuit in Geth: in quo vir fuit excelsus, qui senos in manibus pedibusque habebat digitos, id est, viginti quattuor, et erat de origine Arapha.

verses.textEn: And he blasphemed Israel. So Jonathan, the son of Shimei, the brother of David, struck him down.
verses.textLa: Et blasphemavit Israel: percussit autem eum Ionathan filius Samaa fratris David.
verses.notes: Israel is not God, so how can anyone blaspheme against Israel? by saying something against Israel that implies something blasphemous against God.

verses.textEn: These four men were born of Arapha in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and his servants.
verses.textLa: Hi quattuor nati sunt de Arapha in Geth, et ceciderunt in manu David, et servorum eius.

verses.textEn: And David spoke to the Lord the words of this verse, in the day that the Lord freed him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
verses.textLa: Locutus est autem David Domino verba carminis huius, in die qua liberavit eum Dominus de manu omnium inimicorum suorum, et de manu Saul,

verses.textEn: And he said: “The Lord is my rock, and my strength, and my Savior.
verses.textLa: et ait: Dominus petra mea, et robur meum, et salvator meus.

verses.textEn: I will hope in him. God is my strong one, my shield, and the horn of my salvation. He lifts me up, and he is my refreshment. You, O my Savior, will free me from iniquity.
verses.textLa: Deus fortis meus sperabo in eum: scutum meum, et cornu salutis meæ: elevator meus, et refugium meum: salvator meus, de iniquitate liberabis me.

verses.textEn: I will call upon the Lord, who is praiseworthy; and I will be saved from my enemies.
verses.textLa: Laudabilem invocabo Dominum: et ab inimicis meis salvus ero.

verses.textEn: For the pangs of death have encircled me. The torrents of Belial have terrified me.
verses.textLa: Quia circumdederunt me contritiones mortis: torrentes Belial terruerunt me.

verses.textEn: The ropes of Hell have encompassed me. The snares of death have intercepted me.
verses.textLa: Funes inferni circumdederunt me: prævenerunt me laquei mortis.

verses.textEn: In my tribulation, I will call upon the Lord, and I will cry out to my God. And he will heed my voice from his temple, and my outcry will reach his ears.
verses.textLa: In tribulatione mea invocabo Dominum, et ad Deum meum clamabo: et exaudiet de templo suo vocem meam, et clamor meus venit ad aures eius.

verses.textEn: The earth was shaken, and it quaked. The foundations of the mountains were struck together and violently shaken, because he was angry with them.
verses.textLa: Commota est et contremuit terra: fundamenta montium concussa sunt, et conquassata, quoniam iratus est eis.

verses.textEn: Smoke ascends from his nostrils, and fire from his mouth will devour; coals have been kindled by it.
verses.textLa: Ascendit fumus de naribus eius, et ignis de ore eius vorabit: carbones succensi sunt ab eo.

verses.textEn: He bent down the heavens, and it descended; and a fog was beneath his feet.
verses.textLa: Inclinavit cælos, et descendit: et caligo sub pedibus eius.

verses.textEn: And he climbed upon the cherubim, and he flew; and he slid upon the wings of the wind.
verses.textLa: Et ascendit super cherubim, et volavit: et lapsus est super pennas venti.

verses.textEn: He set darkness as a hiding place around himself, with waters sifted from the clouds of the heavens.
verses.textLa: Posuit tenebras in circuitu suo latibulum: cribrans aquas de nubibus cælorum.

verses.textEn: By means of the brightness of his glance, coals of fire were kindled.
verses.textLa: Præ fulgore in conspectu eius, succensi sunt carbones ignis.

verses.textEn: The Lord will thunder from heaven; and the Most High will utter his voice.
verses.textLa: Tonabit de cælo Dominus: et Excelsus dabit vocem suam.

verses.textEn: He shot arrows, and he scattered them; lightning, and he consumed them.
verses.textLa: Misit sagittas et dissipavit eos: fulgur, et consumpsit eos.

verses.textEn: And the overflow of the sea appeared, and the foundations of the globe were revealed, at the rebuke of the Lord, at the exhale of the breath of his fury.
verses.textLa: Et apparuerunt effusiones maris, et revelata sunt fundamenta orbis ab increpatione Domini, ab inspiratione spiritus furoris eius.

verses.textEn: He sent from on high, and he took me up. And he drew me out of many waters.
verses.textLa: Misit de excelso, et assumpsit me: et extraxit me de aquis multis.

verses.textEn: He freed me from my most powerful enemy and from those who had hated me. For they were too strong for me.
verses.textLa: Liberavit me ab inimico meo potentissimo, et ab his qui oderant me: quoniam robustiores me erant.

verses.textEn: He went before me in the day of my affliction, and the Lord became my firmament.
verses.textLa: Prævenit me in die afflictionis meæ, et factus est Dominus firmamentum meum.

verses.textEn: And he led me out to a wide-open place. He freed me, because I was pleasing to him.
verses.textLa: Et eduxit me in latitudinem: liberavit me, quia complacui ei.

verses.textEn: The Lord will reward me according to my justice. And he will repay me according to the cleanness of my hands.
verses.textLa: Retribuet mihi Dominus secundum iustitiam meam: et secundum munditiam manuum mearum reddet mihi.

verses.textEn: For I have kept to the ways of the Lord, and I have not acted impiously before my God.
verses.textLa: Quia custodivi vias Domini, et non egi impie, a Deo meo.

verses.textEn: For all his judgments are in my sight. And I have not removed his precepts from me.
verses.textLa: Omnia enim iudicia eius in conspectu meo: et præcepta eius non amovi a me.

verses.textEn: And I shall be perfect with him. And I shall guard myself from my own iniquity.
verses.textLa: Et ero perfectus cum eo: et custodiam me ab iniquitate mea.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will recompense me according to my justice, and according to the cleanness of my hands in the sight of his eyes.
verses.textLa: Et restituet mihi Dominus secundum iustitiam meam: et secundum munditiam manuum mearum, in conspectu oculorum suorum.

verses.textEn: With the holy one, you will be holy, and with the strong one, you will be perfect.
verses.textLa: Cum sancto sanctus eris: et cum robusto perfectus.

verses.textEn: With the elect one, you will be elect, and with the perverse one, you will be perverse.
verses.textLa: Cum electo electus eris: et cum perverso perverteris.

verses.textEn: And you will bring to salvation the poor people, and you will humble the exalted with your eyes.
verses.textLa: Et populum pauperem salvum facies: oculisque tuis excelsos humiliabis.

verses.textEn: For you are my lamp, O Lord. And you, O Lord, will illuminate my darkness.
verses.textLa: Quia tu lucerna mea Domine: et tu Domine illuminabis tenebras meas.

verses.textEn: For in you, I will run girded. In my God, I will leap over the wall.
verses.textLa: In te enim curram accinctus: in Deo meo transiliam murum.

verses.textEn: God, his way is immaculate; the eloquence of the Lord is an exacting fire. He is the shield of all who hope in him.
verses.textLa: Deus, immaculata via eius, eloquium Domini igne examinatum: scutum est omnium sperantium in se.

verses.textEn: Who is God except the Lord? And who is strong except our God?
verses.textLa: Quis est Deus præter Dominum: et quis fortis præter Deum nostrum?

verses.textEn: God, he has girded me with fortitude, and he has made my way perfect:
verses.textLa: Deus qui accinxit me fortitudine: et complanavit perfectam viam meam.

verses.textEn: making my feet like the feet of the stag, and stationing me upon my exalted places,
verses.textLa: Coæquans pedes meos cervis, et super excelsa mea statuens me.

verses.textEn: teaching my hands to do battle, and making my arms like a bow of brass.
verses.textLa: Docens manus meas ad prælium, et componens quasi arcum æreum brachia mea.

verses.textEn: You have given me the shield of your salvation. And your mildness has multiplied me.
verses.textLa: Dedisti mihi clypeum salutis tuæ: et mansuetudo tua multiplicavit me.

verses.textEn: You will enlarge my steps under me, and my ankles will not fail.
verses.textLa: Dilatabis gressus meos subtus me: et non deficient tali mei.

verses.textEn: I will pursue my enemies, and crush them. And I will not turn back, until I consume them.
verses.textLa: Persequar inimicos meos, et conteram: et non convertar donec consumam eos.

verses.textEn: I will consume them and break them apart, so that they cannot rise up; they will fall under my feet.
verses.textLa: Consumam eos et confringam, ut non consurgant: cadent sub pedibus meis.

verses.textEn: You have girded me with strength for the battle. Those who resisted me, you have bent down under me.
verses.textLa: Accinxisti me fortitudine ad prælium: incurvasti resistentes mihi subtus me.

verses.textEn: You have caused my enemies to turn their back to me; they have hatred for me, and I shall destroy them.
verses.textLa: Inimicos meos dedisti mihi dorsum: odientes me, et disperdam eos.

verses.textEn: They will cry out, and there will be no one to save; to the Lord, and he will not heed them.
verses.textLa: Clamabunt, et non erit qui salvet, ad Dominum, et non exaudiet eos.

verses.textEn: I will wipe them away like the dust of the earth. I will break them apart and crush them, like the mud of the streets.
verses.textLa: Delebo eos ut pulverem terræ: quasi lutum platearum comminuam eos atque confringam.

verses.textEn: You will save me from the contradictions of my people. You will preserve me to be the head of the Gentiles; a people I do not know shall serve me.
verses.textLa: Salvabis me a contradictionibus populi mei: custodies me in caput Gentium: populus, quem ignoro, serviet mihi.

verses.textEn: The sons of foreigners, who will resist me, at the hearing of the ear they will be obedient to me.
verses.textLa: Filii alieni resistent mihi, auditu auris obedient mihi.

verses.textEn: The foreigners flowed away, but they will be drawn together in their anguishes.
verses.textLa: Filii alieni defluxerunt, et contrahentur in angustiis suis.

verses.textEn: The Lord lives, and my God is blessed. And the strong God of my salvation shall be exalted.
verses.textLa: Vivit Dominus, et benedictus Deus meus: et exaltabitur Deus fortis salutis meæ.

verses.textEn: God gives me vindication, and he casts down the peoples under me.
verses.textLa: Deus qui das vindictas mihi, et deiicis populos sub me.

verses.textEn: He leads me away from my enemies, and he lifts me up from those who resist me. You will free me from the iniquitous man.
verses.textLa: Qui educis me ab inimicis meis, et a resistentibus mihi elevas me: a viro iniquo liberabis me:

verses.textEn: Because of this, I will confess to you, O Lord, among the Gentiles, and I will sing to your name:
verses.textLa: Propterea confitebor tibi Domine in gentibus: et nomini tuo cantabo.

verses.textEn: magnifying the salvation of his king, and showing mercy to David, his Christ, and to his offspring forever.”
verses.textLa: Magnificans salutes regis sui, et faciens misericordiam Christo suo David, et semini eius in sempiternum.

verses.textEn: These are the last words of David. Now David, the son of Jesse, the man to whom it was appointed concerning the Christ of the God of Jacob, the preeminent psalmist of Israel said:
verses.textLa: Hæc autem sunt verba David novissima. Dixit David filius Isai: Dixit vir, cui constitutum est de Christo Dei Iacob, egregius psaltes Israel:

verses.textEn: “The Spirit of the Lord has spoken through me, and his word was spoken through my tongue.
verses.textLa: Spiritus Domini locutus est per me, et sermo eius per linguam meam.

verses.textEn: The God of Israel spoke to me, the Strong One of Israel spoke, the Ruler of men, the Just Ruler, in the fear of God,
verses.textLa: Dixit Deus Israel mihi, locutus est Fortis Israel, Dominator hominum, iustus dominator in timore Dei:

verses.textEn: like the first light of the morning as the sun is rising, when a morning without clouds glows red, and like plants springing forth from the earth after a rainfall.
verses.textLa: sicut lux auroræ, oriente sole, mane absque nubibus rutilat, et sicut pluviis germinat herba de terra.

verses.textEn: But my house is not so great with God that he should undertake an eternal covenant with me, firm and fortified in all things. For he is the entirety of my salvation and the entirety of my will. And there is nothing of this which will not spring forth.
verses.textLa: Nec tanta est domus mea apud Deum, ut pactum æternum iniret mecum firmum in omnibus atque munitum. Cuncta enim salus mea, et omnis voluntas: nec est quidquam ex ea quod non germinet.

verses.textEn: But all prevaricators shall be plucked out like thorns, yet they are not taken away by hands.
verses.textLa: Prævaricatores autem quasi spinæ evellentur universi: quæ non tolluntur manibus.

verses.textEn: And if anyone wishes to touch them, he must be armed with iron and a wooden lance. And they shall be set ablaze and burned to nothing.”
verses.textLa: Et si quis tangere voluerit eas, armabitur ferro et ligno lanceato, igneque succensæ comburentur, usque ad nihilum.

verses.textEn: These are the names of the valiant of David. Sitting in the chair was the wisest leader among the three; he was like a very tender little worm in a tree, who killed eight hundred men in one attack.
verses.textLa: Hæc nomina fortium David. Sedens in cathedra sapientissimus princeps inter tres, ipse est quasi tenerrimus ligni vermiculus, qui octingentos interfecit impetu uno.

verses.textEn: After him, there was Eleazar, the son of his paternal uncle, an Ahohite, who was among the three valiant men who were with David when they chastised the Philistines, and they were gathered together in battle there.
verses.textLa: Post hunc, Eleazar filius patrui eius Ahohites inter tres fortes, qui erant cum David quando exprobraverunt Philisthiim, et congregati sunt illuc in prælium.

verses.textEn: And when the men of Israel had gone up, he himself stood fast and struck down the Philistines, until his hand grew weak and stiff with the sword. And the Lord wrought a great salvation on that day. And the people who had fled returned to take up the spoils of the slain.
verses.textLa: Cumque ascendissent viri Israel, ipse stetit et percussit Philisthæos donec deficeret manus eius, et obrigesceret cum gladio: fecitque Dominus salutem magnam in die illa: et populus, qui fugerat, reversus est ad cæsorum spolia detrahenda.

verses.textEn: And after him, there was Shammah, the son of Agee, from Hara. And the Philistines gathered together at an outpost. For a field full of lentils was in that place. And when the people had fled from the face of the Philistines,
verses.textLa: Et post hunc, Semma filius Age de Arari. Et congregati sunt Philisthiim in statione: erat quippe ibi ager lente plenus. Cumque fugisset populus a facie Philisthiim,

verses.textEn: he stood fast in the middle of the field, and it was protected by him. And he struck down the Philistines. And the Lord wrought a great salvation.
verses.textLa: stetit ille in medio agri, et tuitus est eum, percussitque Philisthæos: et fecit Dominus salutem magnam.

verses.textEn: And moreover, before this, the three who were leaders among the thirty descended and went to David at harvest time, in the cave of Adullam. But the camp of the Philistines was positioned in the Valley of the giants.
verses.textLa: Necnon et ante descenderant tres qui erant principes inter triginta, et venerant tempore messis ad David in speluncam Odollam: castra autem Philisthinorum erant posita in Valle gigantum.

verses.textEn: And David was in a stronghold. Moreover, there was a garrison of the Philistines at that time in Bethlehem.
verses.textLa: Et David erat in præsidio: porro statio Philisthinorum tunc erat in Bethlehem.

verses.textEn: Then David desired, and he said, “If only someone would give me a drink of the water from the cistern, which is in Bethlehem beside the gate!”
verses.textLa: Desideravit ergo David, et ait: O si quis mihi daret potum aquæ de cisterna, quæ est in Bethlehem iuxta portam!

verses.textEn: Therefore, the three valiant men burst into the encampment of the Philistines, and they drew water from the cistern of Bethlehem, which was beside the gate. And they brought it to David. Yet he was not willing to drink; instead, he poured it out to the Lord,
verses.textLa: Irruperunt ergo tres fortes castra Philisthinorum, et hauserunt aquam de cisterna Bethlehem, quæ erat iuxta portam, et attulerunt ad David: at ille noluit bibere, sed libavit eam Domino,

verses.textEn: saying: “May the Lord be gracious to me, so that I may not do this. Should I drink the blood of these men who have set out to the peril of their own lives?” Therefore, he was not willing to drink. These things were accomplished by these three robust men.
verses.textLa: dicens: Propitius sit mihi Dominus, ne faciam hoc: num sanguinem hominum istorum, qui profecti sunt, et animarum periculum bibam? Noluit ergo bibere. Hæc fecerunt tres robustissimi.

verses.textEn: Also Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was first among the three. It was he who lifted up his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed. And he was renowned among the three,
verses.textLa: Abisai quoque frater Ioab filius Sarviæ, princeps erat de tribus: ipse est qui levavit hastam suam contra trecentos, quos interfecit, nominatus in tribus,

verses.textEn: and he was the noblest of the three, and he was their leader. But at first he did not attain to the three.
verses.textLa: et inter tres nobilior, eratque eorum princeps, sed usque ad tres primos non pervenerat.

verses.textEn: And Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, a very strong man of great deeds, was from Kabzeel. He slew the two lions of Moab, and he descended and slew a lion in the middle of a den, in the days of snow.
verses.textLa: Et Banaias filius Ioiadæ viri fortissimi, magnorum operum, de Cabseel: ipse percussit duos leones Moab, et ipse descendit, et percussit leonem in media cisterna in diebus nivis.

verses.textEn: He also killed an Egyptian who had a spear in his hand, a man worthy to behold. And yet he had gone down to him with only a staff. And he forced the spear from the hand of the Egyptian, and he killed him with his own spear.
verses.textLa: Ipse quoque interfecit virum Ægyptium, virum dignum spectaculo, habentem in manu hastam: itaque cum descendisset ad eum in virga, vi extorsit hastam de manu Ægyptii, et interfecit eum hasta sua.

verses.textEn: Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, accomplished these things.
verses.textLa: Hæc fecit Banaias filius Ioiadæ.

verses.textEn: And he was renowned among the three robust men, who were the most noble among the thirty. Yet truly, he did not attain to the three, until David made him his secret advisor.
verses.textLa: Et ipse nominatus inter tres robustos, qui erant inter triginta nobiliores: verumtamen usque ad tres non pervenerat: fecitque eum sibi David auricularium, a secreto.

verses.textEn: Among the thirty were: Asahel, the brother of Joab, Elhanan, the son of his paternal uncle, from Bethlehem,
verses.textLa: Asael frater Ioab inter triginta, Elehanan filius patrui eius de Bethlehem,

verses.textEn: Shammah from Harod, Elika from Harod,
verses.textLa: Semma de Harodi, Elica de Harodi,

verses.textEn: Helez from Palti, Ira, the son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa,
verses.textLa: Heles de Phalti, Hira filius Acces de Thecua,

verses.textEn: Abiezer from Anathoth, Mebunnai from Hushah,
verses.textLa: Abiezer de Anathoth, Mobonnai de Husati,

verses.textEn: Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
verses.textLa: Selmon Ahohites, Maharai Netophathites,

verses.textEn: Heleb, the son of Baanah, also himself a Netophathite, Ittai, the son of Ribai, from Gibeah, of the sons of Benjamin,
verses.textLa: Heled filius Baana, et ipse Netophathites, Ithai filius Ribai de Gabaath filiorum Beniamin,

verses.textEn: Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the Torrent Gaash,
verses.textLa: Banaia Pharathonites, Heddai de Torrente Gaas,

verses.textEn: Abialbon the Arbathite, Azmaveth from Beromi,
verses.textLa: Abialbon Arbathites, Azmaveth de Beromi,

verses.textEn: Eliahba from Shaalbon; the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,
verses.textLa: Eliaba de Salaboni. Filii Iassen, Ionathan,

verses.textEn: Shammah from Orori, Ahiam, the son of Sharar, the Hararite,
verses.textLa: Semma de Orori, Aiam filius Sarar Arorites,

verses.textEn: Eliphelet, the son of Ahasbai, the son of Maacath, Eliam, the son of Ahithophel, the Gilonite,
verses.textLa: Eliphelet filius Aasbai filii Machati, Eliam filius Achitophel Gelonites,

verses.textEn: Hezrai from Carmel, Paarai from Arbi,
verses.textLa: Hesrai de Carmelo, Pharai de Arbi,

verses.textEn: Igal, the son of Nathan, from Zobah, Bani from Gad,
verses.textLa: Igaal filius Nathan de Soba, Bonni de Gadi,

verses.textEn: Zelek from Ammon, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor bearer of Joab, the son of Zeruiah,
verses.textLa: Selec de Ammoni, Naharai Berothites armiger Ioab filii Sarviæ,

verses.textEn: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb also an Ithrite,
verses.textLa: Ira Iethrites, Gareb et ipse Iethrites,

verses.textEn: Uriah the Hittite: altogether thirty seven
verses.textLa: Urias Hethæus. Omnes triginta septem.

verses.textEn: And the fury of the Lord was again kindled against Israel, and he stirred up David among them, saying: “Go, number Israel and Judah.”
verses.textLa: Et addidit furor Domini irasci contra Israel, commovitque David in eis dicentem: Vade, numera Israel et Iudam.

verses.textEn: And the king said to Joab, the leader of his army, “Travel through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and number the people, so that I may know their number.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque rex ad Ioab principem exercitus sui: Perambula omnes tribus Israel a Dan usque Bersabee, et numerate populum, ut sciam numerum eius.

verses.textEn: And Joab said to the king: “May the Lord your God increase your people, who are already great in number, and may he again increase them, one hundredfold, in the sight of my lord the king. But what does my lord the king intend for himself by this kind of thing?”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Ioab regi: Adaugeat Dominus Deus tuus ad populum tuum, quantus nunc est, iterumque centuplicet in conspectu domini mei regis: sed quid sibi dominus meus rex vult in re huiuscemodi?

verses.textEn: But the words of the king prevailed over the words of Joab and the leaders of the army. And so Joab and the leaders of the military departed from the face of the king, so that they might number the people of Israel.
verses.textLa: Obtinuit autem sermo regis verba Ioab, et principum exercitus: egressusque est Ioab, et princeps militum a facie regis, ut numerarent populum Israel.

verses.textEn: And when they had passed across the Jordan, they arrived at Aroer, to the right of the city, which is in the Valley of Gad.
verses.textLa: Cumque pertransissent Iordanem, venerunt in Aroer ad dexteram urbis, quæ est in Valle Gad:

verses.textEn: And they continued on through Jazer, into Gilead, and to the lower land of Hodsi. And they arrived in the woodlands of Dan. And going around beside Sidon,
verses.textLa: et per Iazer transierunt in Galaad, et in terram inferiorem Hodsi, et venerunt in Dan silvestria. Circumeuntesque iuxta Sidonem,

verses.textEn: they passed near the walls of Tyre, and near all the land of the Hivite and the Canaanite. And they went into the south of Judah, to Beersheba.
verses.textLa: transierunt prope mœnia Tyri, et omnem terram Hevæi et Chananæi, veneruntque ad meridiem Iuda in Bersabee:

verses.textEn: And having inspected the entire land, after nine months and twenty days, they were present in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: et lustrata universa terra, affuerunt post novem menses et viginti dies in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: Then Joab gave the number of the description of the people to the king. And there were found of Israel eight hundred thousand able-bodied men, who might draw the sword; and of Judah, five hundred thousand fighting men.
verses.textLa: Dedit ergo Ioab numerum descriptionis populi regi, et inventa sunt de Israel octingenta millia virorum fortium, qui educerent gladium: et de Iuda quingenta millia pugnatorum.

verses.textEn: Then the heart of David struck him, after the people were numbered. And David said to the Lord: “I have sinned greatly in what I have done. But I pray that you, O Lord, may take away the iniquity of your servant. For I have acted very foolishly.”
verses.textLa: Percussit autem cor David eum, postquam numeratus est populus: et dixit David ad Dominum: Peccavi valde in hoc facto: sed precor Domine, ut transferas iniquitatem servi tui, quia stulte egi nimis.

verses.textEn: And David rose up in the morning, and the word of the Lord went to Gad, the prophet and seer of David, saying:
verses.textLa: Surrexit itaque David mane, et sermo Domini factus est ad Gad prophetam et videntem David, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Go, and say to David: ‘Thus says the Lord: I present to you a choice of three things. Choose one of these, whichever you will, so that I may do it to you.’ ”
verses.textLa: Vade, et loquere ad David: Hæc dicit Dominus: Trium tibi datur optio, elige unum quod volueris ex his, ut faciam tibi.

verses.textEn: And when Gad had gone to David, he announced it to him, saying: “Either seven years of famine will come to you in your land; or you will flee for three months from your adversaries, and they will pursue you; or there will be a pestilence in your land for three days. Now then, deliberate, and see what word I may respond to him who sent me.”
verses.textLa: Cumque venisset Gad ad David, nunciavit ei, dicens: Aut septem annis veniet tibi fames in terra tua: aut tribus mensibus fugies adversarios tuos, et ille te persequentur: aut certe tribus diebus erit pestilentia in terra tua. Nunc ergo delibera, et vide quem respondeam ei, qui me misit, sermonem.

verses.textEn: Then David said to Gad: “I am in great anguish. But it is better that I should fall into the hands of the Lord (for his mercies are many) than into the hands of men.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem David ad Gad: Coarctor nimis: sed melius est ut incidam in manus Domini (multæ enim misericordiæ eius sunt) quam in manus hominum.

verses.textEn: And the Lord sent a pestilence upon Israel, from the morning until the appointed time. And there died of the people, from Dan to Beersheba, seventy thousand men.
verses.textLa: Immisitque Dominus pestilentiam in Israel, de mane usque ad tempus constitutum, et mortui sunt ex populo a Dan usque ad Bersabee septuaginta millia virorum.

verses.textEn: And when the Angel of the Lord had extended his hand over Jerusalem, so that he might destroy it, the Lord took pity on the affliction. And he said to the Angel who was striking the people: “It is enough. Hold back your hand now.” And the Angel of the Lord was beside the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
verses.textLa: Cumque extendisset manum suam Angelus Domini super Ierusalem ut disperderet eam, misertus est Dominus super afflictione, et ait Angelo percutienti populum: Sufficit: nunc contine manum tuam. Erat autem Angelus Domini iuxta aream Areuna Iebusæi.

verses.textEn: And when he had seen the Angel cutting down the people, David said to the Lord: “I am the one who sinned. I have acted iniquitously. These ones who are the sheep, what have they done? I beg you that your hand may be turned against me and against my father’s house.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque David ad Dominum cum vidisset Angelum cædentem populum: Ego sum qui peccavi, ego inique egi: isti qui oves sunt, quid fecerunt? Vertatur, obsecro, manus tua contra me, et contra domum patris mei.

verses.textEn: Then Gad went to David on that day, and he said, “Ascend and construct an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
verses.textLa: Venit autem Gad ad David in die illa, et dixit ei: Ascende, et constitue altare Domino in area Areuna Iebusæi.

verses.textEn: And David ascended in accord with the word of Gad, which the Lord had commanded to him.
verses.textLa: Et ascendit David iuxta sermonem Gad, quem præceperat ei Dominus.

verses.textEn: And looking out, Araunah turned his attention to the king and his servants, passing toward him.
verses.textLa: Conspiciensque Areuna, animadvertit regem et servos eius transire ad se:

verses.textEn: And going out, he adored the king, lying prone with his face to the ground, and he said, “What is the reason that my lord the king has come to his servant?” And David said to him, “So as to purchase the threshing floor from you, and to build an altar to the Lord, and to quiet the plague that rages among the people.”
verses.textLa: et egressus adoravit regem prono vultu in terram, et ait: Quid causæ est ut veniat dominus meus rex ad servum suum? Cui David ait: Ut emam a te aream, et ædificem altare Domino, et cesset interfectio quæ grassatur in populo.

verses.textEn: And Araunah said to David: “May my lord the king offer and accept whatever is pleasing to him. You have oxen for a holocaust, and the cart and the yokes of the oxen to use for wood.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Areuna ad David: Accipiat, et offerat dominus meus rex, sicut placet ei: habes boves in holocaustum, et plaustrum, et iuga boum in usum lignorum.

verses.textEn: All these things Araunah gave, as a king to a king. And Araunah said to the king, “May the Lord your God accept your vow.”
verses.textLa: Omnia dedit Areuna rex regi: dixitque Areuna ad regem: Dominus Deus tuus suscipiat votum tuum.
verses.notes: This first part of the verses is not a quote. Areuna is not referring to himself by name in the third person

verses.textEn: And in response, the king said to him: “It shall not be as you wish. Instead, I will purchase it from you at a price. For I will not offer to the Lord, my God, holocausts that cost nothing.” Therefore, David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
verses.textLa: Cui respondens rex, ait: Nequaquam ut vis, sed emam pretio a te, et non offeram Domino Deo meo holocausta gratuita. Emit ergo David aream, et boves, argenti siclis quinquaginta:

verses.textEn: And in that place, David built an altar to the Lord. And he offered holocausts and peace offerings. And the Lord was gracious to the land, and the plague was held back from Israel.
verses.textLa: et ædificavit ibi David altare Domino, et obtulit holocausta et pacifica: et propitiatus est Dominus terræ, et cohibita est plaga ab Israel.
